Problem:
Consider a complex variable function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) subjected to the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Dz \\), where \\( D \\) is a constant complex number. Analyze how the application of the transformation \\( f(z) = e^{Ut}z \\) affects z over time t, where \\( U \\) is also a constant complex number.

If the transformation \\( f(z) \\) is applied to a complex number \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{z} = Dz \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\dot{z} = Dz \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( f(z) \\) modifies the initial condition by scaling it with \\( e^{Ut} \\), thus changing the trajectory. Since the trajectories depend exponentially on the time t and the constants \\( U \\) and \\( D \\), they will not end up the same unless \\( U = 0 \\).

causal_map_integration: The application of the transformation U to z results in f(z), which then influences z(t) over time. The initial condition z_0 at t=0 transforms to z through f(z), and this z evolves according to D to become z(t). Without further intervention, applying f(z) followed by evolution under D from t=0 to t=T will yield the same z(T) as directly evolving z_0 under D from t=0 to t=T.
